title: codehw3
text:
GitHub repo: https://github.com/wywydubs/ENVS-193DS_homework-03
message = FALSE # hide messages
warning = FALSE # hide warning


library(tidyverse) # Load packages
library(here)
library(gt) # chose gt

library(janitor) # Optional packages
library(readxl)
library(readr)

title: codehw3
text:
a. Data Summarizing
I could compare the average time it took to get out of bed comparing alarm used versus not used. I would want to know if getting out of bed after a natural wake up could be different on average than from an alarm, as there are different factors like morning obligations hence an alarm versus less grogginess from waking up naturally. This comparison could be done by finding the mean of days with alarm use and the mean of no alarm use, and it could inform me more about the impact of alarms on my morning routine.

title: codehw3
text:
b. Visualization

message = FALSE # hide messages
warning = FALSE # hide warning

sleep_log <- read_csv("../data/sleep_log.csv") #read in data


ggplot(sleep_log, aes(x = `Alarm used?`, # set x and y
                      y = `Time it took to get out of bed (min)`)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0, aes(color = `Alarm used?`)) +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "point", 
               shape = 18, size = 4, color = "black") + # add in mean
  stat_summary(fun.data = mean_se, geom = "errorbar", 
               width = 0.2, color = "black") + #add in error bars
  labs(
    title = "Minutes to Get Out of Bed with vs without Alarm", 
    x = "Alarm Used?",
    y = "Minutes to Get Out of Bed"
    # change title + x and y titles
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Yes" = "deeppink", "No" = "purple")) +
  theme_minimal()







# change theme to minimal and add color to values

title: codehw3
text:
c.¬†Caption
Figure 1, above, titled ‚ÄúMinutes to Get Out of Bed‚Äù, with two jitterplots, purple circular points representing days where alarms were not used and pink circular points representing days when an alarm was used. The y axis represents how long it took to get out of bed, and the mean for each group is represented by a black diamond with error bars represented by black bars.

title: codehw3
text:
d.¬†Table Presentation

summary_table <- sleep_log |> # assign to sleep log
  group_by(`Alarm used?`) |>  # set categories
  summarise(
    `Average time to get out of bed (min)` = 
      round(mean(`Time it took to get out of bed (min)`, na.rm = TRUE), 1), 
    # round data to one decimal point
    sample = n() # add in sample size
  )
# Display with gt
summary_table |> 
  gt() |>  #use gt
  tab_header(
    title = "Average Time to Get Out of Bed", # set title
    subtitle = "Grouped by Alarm Use" #set subtitle
  )







Average Time to Get Out of Bed


Grouped by Alarm Use


Alarm used?
Average time to get out of bed (min)
sample




No
14.2
12


Yes
11.5
11

title: codehw3
text:
a. Description
An affective visualization for my data could go a variety of ways. I think it probably be focused around two very contrasting styles, maybe a jagged blue landscape with a darkened ghoul of some sort to represent days which require an alarm wakeup. This could be contrasted by a smooth, warm hued style with a peaceful visually appealing creature in order to represent a natural wakeup. This would evoke an emotional response to my topic that data obviously couldn‚Äôt convey. I want to do this and highlight the fact that besides my alarm wakeup, the data looks exactly the same, but the emotion behind it is very different.

title: codehw3
text:
b. Sketch

knitr::include_graphics("sketch1.png") # insert image

title: codehw3
text:
c.¬†Draft of Visualization

knitr::include_graphics("IMG_0020.jpg") # insert image

title: codehw3
text:
d.¬†Artist Statement
This piece shows the hidden emotion behind what appears to be very similar data, via a gradient with a ghoulish creature on one side with sharp, jagged, tortured surroundings to represent waking up with an alarm and a calm peaceful gnome with smooth features and background to represent waking up naturally, with similar wake up times and times to get out of bed I used some reference photos for the creatures from online but there wasn‚Äôt really any outside influence or style. The closest would be some form of dark fantasy style? The form of the work is on a drawing app using an apple pen. I create this by making the gradient background and then drawing on it using the app.

title: codehw3
text:
a. Revise and Summarize
The authors used panel data regression estimated using Ordinary Least Squares (OLS). Response variable is renewable electricity production and the predictor is Islam financing and Sukuk.

knitr::include_graphics("islam_table.png") #add in islam image

title: codehw3
text:
b. Visual Clarity
The table clearly represents the data underlying the statistical tests, and each column labeled and values are super precise. It includes coefficients, standard errors, t-statistics, p-values, and significance levels, which help to interpret the reliability of the work. The formatting is clean and makes it easy to compare variables.

title: codehw3
text:
c.¬†Aesthetic Clarity
The aesthetic is and clean and doesn‚Äôt have too many grid lines, while important p values are highlighted nicely using asterisks, and the data is nicely spaced. The precise nature of the data can be a little overwhelming with all of the decimals, but it is still manageable.

title: codehw3
text:
d.¬†Suggestions
Confidence intervals might help the data, and potentially coloring or bolding really important values could assist them further in getting their point across. For more readability, a key with definitions for all of the words could be of worth as well.

text: I love all sorts of music, and recently, I‚Äôve been listening to some pretty unique stuff. This playlist contains some stuff I definitely wouldn‚Äôt throw on at a party, as it certainly has some unique stylistic qualities. Check it out if you would like!

text:

Ultimate frisbee is a huge part of my life, especially when it comes to diving and blocking a disc (commonly referred to as laying out). Here‚Äôs a couple pictures of me risking abdominal injury and the rest of my team!

title: Favorite Hobbies, Classes, and Interests
text:
‚öæ Sports!!
I could talk about and watch sports all day every day. I‚Äôm a diehard 49ers, Giants, and Warriors fan, and tend to spend any money I have laying around on going to games! Here are some pictures of me supporting my teams in person over the years.

title: Projects
text:
193DS: Homework 3


A homework assignment in R Studio that required graph and table data visualization, affective data visualization, and statistical critique. A very challenging assignment‚Ä¶


















193PE: Politcal Ecology of World Cups Final Presentation


A final group presentation exploring the ecological implications of mega-events using Brazil and South Africa as case studies, using a Political Ecology lense.












No matching items

title: 193PE: Politcal Ecology of World Cups Final Presentation
text: Completed in Spring 2025, the culminating class for Environmental Studies 193PE (Introduction to Political Ecology), was to investigate and present a ~20 minute research question in relation to any given environmental topic. Along with this, subsequent application of Political Ecology concepts to the topic were required, drawing on Paul Robbin‚Äôs ‚ÄúPolitical Ecology: A Critical Introduction (2019)‚Äù found here.

title: 193DS: Homework 3
text: GitHub repo: https://github.com/wywydubs/ENVS-193DS_homework-03

title: Wyatt Dunn
text: Hello! I‚Äôm Wyatt, a rising 3rd year at the University of California, Santa Barbara. I am working towards a double major in Environmental Studies (B.A.) and Economics (B.A.). I enjoy playing Ultimate Frisbee (it‚Äôs not anything like disc golf) running around outside, and supporting anything bay area sports. I‚Äôm excited to keep pursuing things that connect my interests of money and the environment, and make the two less antithetical from one another. Welcome to my website!

title: About
text:
Where am I?
After spending the first 18 years of my life in Marin County California with my parents, sister, and 3 cats, I enrolled at UCSB for the 2023-24 school year and am now a rising junior. When I‚Äôm not in Santa Barbara, you can find me in Upstate New York, where I work at a sleepaway summer camp, usually in charge of the 5-9 year old section.

title: About
text:
What do I like?
A lot of things! Making charcuterie boards, being out in nature (Upstate New York has a lot of that), going to the gym, tossing a frisbee around, and generally anything that involves moving my body. I also work at Snag, the local scooter delivery service around UCSB, so catch me on a lime scooter too!

title: About
section: What am I looking forward to?
text:
What am I looking forward to?
I‚Äôm excited to continue my upper division learning within Environmental Studies, and progress further in my Economics path. I‚Äôm hoping to find an internship next school year that intersects those two. I also can‚Äôt wait to play for our local club ultimate frisbee team this summer and fall, Offshore Ultimate!
